discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Dai is at 1.04, going towards 1.05. Should we fix the peg with an emergency vote to lower stablecoin LR and increase stablecoin DC?

content.content: The peg is so horribly broken that it’s very hard to argue the community hasn’t already abandoned the peg, the product, the users, and at this point is just burying its head in the sand. As a user, if you looked at the urgency governance is trying to address this issue - which goes the very heart of the project: Maintaining a stablecoin - Would you feel a sense of confidence that this is the project you can trust with your money? The focus appears to be on raising rates right now??? and discussing features that would take months or years to build. There’s only one solution at this point that can actually fix the peg in the short run, and provide a somewhat acceptable peg and thus product and user experience: lowering stablecoin LR and increasing stablecoin DC. The community has already recognized this as the only viable solution quite a while ago, and is moving towards doing both of these things. But in typical Maker fashion it is happening at a snails pace, with plenty of process, red tape, mips, waiting around, waiting for this or that day, doing more process, waiting even more, taking tiny steps that aren’t commensurate with the magnitude of the problem etc etc. Normally this is a good thing, because in normal situations Maker Governance is supposed to be slow and meticulous. But we are not in normal times, and the instinct to be slow and “risk averse” means we are sleepwalking into the irrelevance and death of this project. There’s absolutely no justification for being so insanely slow when we are destroying out reputation, damaging our users, and just dropping the ball utterly and completely on our core mandate. It’s time to stop with the slow half measures that do nothing. It’s time to stop pretending that bureacracy, process, waiting around and doing barely anything in the name of “being careful” is prudent when we are in the middle of a crisis that has now lasted 6 months, and is only getting worse. We are on the edge of failure and we need to prove to our users that Maker governance isn’t yet a dead player. I propose we take very strong action with risk parameters to immediately bring the dai peg to 1.01, which still won’t be a real long term fix, but will at least provide some short term pain relief, and add some certainty and hope that there is a way forward for this project, while we work on the long term fix which is collateral onboarding with better prioritization that what has been onboarded so far. I propose we create an emergency executive vote for monday with the following parameters: USDC-A LR: 101% USDC-A DC: 250 million PAX LR: 101% PAX DC: 150 million TUSD LR: 101% TUSD DC: 100 million These parameters would hopefully overshoot their DC capacity, meaning that it would create so much pressure on the Dai price above 1.01 that it would create a ceiling of 1.01 that the price couldn’t exceed, until all of the free DC was used up. There are already other polls on the forum that are moving in this direction, just slower. But these polls were from a week ago when the peg didn’t look at horribly broken, and I think people would vote differently if they could see how bad it would get just a short while later, and how it is clearly just gonna continue getting worse and worse if we do nothing. I’m sure at this point some of you have a strong urge to debate and vote and discuss and wait around and make proposals about what the specific risk parameters of this or that should be etc etc etc. But now is way too late for that. If waiting around and having tons of process in the middle of a crisis was so great, why did we reach this point in the first place? Once we take action to relieve pressure immediately, once we get some semblance of control back, then we can go back to having slow process with lots of discussion over details. If the DCs I proposed are way too high, we can easily lower them. But micro management should be done when we are in control, not when we are drowning in our own inertia. I’m giving you a life raft. Will you take it?     yes - cap dai price at 1.01 no - don’t cap dai price abstain     0 voters
content.GPT-summary: The author proposes an emergency executive vote to fix the broken peg of Dai. The proposal suggests lowering stablecoin LR and increasing stablecoin DC. The author criticizes the slow process of Maker Governance and urges for immediate action. The proposal includes specific risk parameters and aims to provide short-term pain relief while working on a long-term solution. The post explains the proposal in detail and asks for feedback through a poll.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author is advertising proposal
None

content.content: Yeah, appreciate the effort, but these aren’t acceptably worded poll options:  Make them credibly neutral. Your job is to find out whether people actually agree with you, not try to manipulate them into agreeing with you and getting the results you want. To be clear, this is fine to some extent in the attached text (though I would still much prefer you tried to present a balanced perspective). But not in the poll options, keep these bias free. Follow the practical guide, read the emergency process post. This is going nowhere as it’s currently presented.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I am voting yes as it is essential to keep the peg. That said, it is a temporary stop-gap. This is not and cannot be a permanent solution. The only sustainable solution is on-boarding collateral. A LOT of it. Signal request is out there now to prioritize Real World Asset onboarding.     [Signal Request] Should Real World Asset collateral onboarding be prioritised in the short term? Governance       Summary of the situation:  The Maker community continues to search for quality collateral assets which can be added to stimulate DAI supply, ease pressure on the DAI peg, and generate liquidity and revenue for the protocol. Some of the new collateral types added since Black Thursday have been successful at this (e.g. USDC-A, WBTC-A which have 40mm and 46mm DAI outstanding against them, respectively), while others were underwhelming (e.g. KNC, ZRX, and MANA which collectively issue just over 500k…
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: edited it now

Yep, that’s better. Please still read the practical guide and follow the points laid out there. It exists to make everyone’s lives easier when interacting with signals. In order for this to pass as a community triggered emergency signal as described here. It needs to:  Have 40 participating voters. Reach a 50% majority. Follow the practical guide as much as possible. Not be brigaded.

content.content: to be clear (as the vote language changed), I am for using a stop-gap (and a lifeboat) currently onboarded stablecoins and lower their LR and increasing the DC… This is a temporary patch. It is recommended for the community to fast track real world assets as they have the added benefit of being a natural liquidity provider.

content.content: 100% yes it can.

Let’s zoom back. There are basically five fundamental phases and milestones to DAI  DAI launches with one digital asset as collateral DAI adds another digital collateral DAI adds first off-chain collateral DAI adds another off-chain collateral DAI minted from off-chain collateral exceeds DAI from on-chain collateral  We are approaching #3. #4 and #5 will happen in 24 months.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: That’s quite the emergency actions. Going from 110% -> 101% CR. Some things to note,  Currently, there’s not even any USDC-A room at all. Maybe things would be different with a much bigger USDC-A buffer. We went from 515M+ DAI supply recently and now we’re at 450M. SF’s were raised across the board a few days ago  Price chart: image981×580 8.79 KB      mrabino1:  That said, it is a temporary stop-gap.   I wouldn’t call this measure temporary, it seems like it’d be around for quite awhile and you won’t be able to revert it.  I’ve mentioned before that even setting a CR of 1.05 does more than capping the price at 1.05, people can still short DAI with high leverage.   I do agree that things have been moving slowly and we need emergency action. We can still do big stablecoin DC increases across the board. And a 105% CR. That’s actually quite a big change. And we still have more gunpowder to cut the CR even lower.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

None of the topics listed match

content.content: I vote for the plan. I don’t like it. There are unknown unknowns. It’s less clean (from my perspective) than Quantitative Easing. Even following this path, we should have a smarter approach like lowering LR gradually and increasing DC gradually as well. But The peg is in a bad shape for months. We lack the coordination to resolve this complex problem in a smart way. We are excited when the peg is above 1.03 but then we hope for a savior like yETH and do nothing (or at least in a slow pace). Our customers are paying for our governance failure and lack of speed. We are using a lot of governance bandwidth on that and not making progress on RWA and other important stuff. That’s not how it should be. I recommend people to read the burning platform memo from Nokia. There is a fire for 4 months now and we are discussing which fire extinguisher we want to use. Let’s vote this thing and let our domain teams micromanage the execution if needed. PS: For those not in the chat => image773×73 12 KB
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: In practice its just not a very compelling proposition to speculatively short the dai price right now. Personally I have lost money doing just that. You’re betting on either dai demand falling, or collateral onboarding picking up. Both of those things are very uncertain and we’d be counting on people participating out of altruism. I think dai users deserve and demand having a user experience supported by hard guarantees, rather than altruists volunteering to take on risk and potential losses. There’s also a negative feedback loop where broken peg inhibits supply growth. The best example of this is the yETH fiasco where the broken peg prevented a potential fix from working safely. If we put these measures proposed here in place, I believe yETH could immediately be turned back on safely.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: It might be our last chance to pause the ETH liquidations and fix the peg this way without much risk. ETH has fallen from the peak of $488 about 10 days ago and is trading around $365. I suggest that instead of the current ETH oracle we use the same oracle as for USDC and that is a constant ($500 is a round number). I voted “Yes” because this is really an unexceptable situation and any solution is better than doing nothing (i.e. talk about RWA, change the rates a few percentages, raise the DCs…). We are also burying our head in sand with relying on centralized stablecoin more and more. Why worry about the (possible temporary) undercollaterization while DAI>$1? The ES won’t be called, and you can always sell as much DAI as you want to USDC and cash out that way.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Liquidations are still off for stable coins? With no plans to implement them soon? Allowing 500 million at 101% LR could very well make Maker bag hold these coins for the foreseeable future as long as DAI >1.00.  Risk premiums don’t really make sense that point, and we will likely be carrying these on the books until DAI <1.00 and the vault owners wish to arbitrage back. It will likely fix the PEG, but then DAI becomes a wrapper for central stable coins, at least for now. Be aware as you vote!
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Jtathmann:  then DAI becomes a wrapper for central stable coins   Painfully, that is needed today. Real World Assets will displace all of the stablecoins. We need a window of time to get there. Once RWAs are coming in at scale, the DC for stablecoins can and should be reduced.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: I think there is nothing bad about DAI becoming the packaging of other central stablecoins, not to mention that this is only a temporary measure, and this situation can be changed by adding other assets in the future. We must solve the most important PEG problem now, and then solve some other problems. There must be a priority.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: yETH nearly restored the peg before it was paused and unwound.  If another version launches soon we might not have to make this decision.

Jtathmann:  Allowing 500 million at 101% LR could very well make Maker bag hold these coins for the foreseeable future as long as DAI >1.00.   This is going to happen regardless of liquidations imo. Not saying that we shouldn’t pursue something like this because of that. The demand for DAI is essentially limitless now given the number of AMM’s including it. This is especially true of curve. Anytime the amount of USDC or USDT increases in curve (or anything like curve), it pushes the DAI price up if there is not enough DAI minted to cover it. In order to mint USDC and USDT, all that needs to happen is dollars entering a bank (and possibly not even that when we’re talking about tether.) In practice the best case outcome here is that DAI becomes largely a wrapper for stablecoins until such a time as the DAI can be supplied from real world assets. This could be years. Unfortunately, this is still the best way to maintain the peg without breaking the ‘1 Dai is backed by $1 of collateral’ promise or implementing negative rates.

content.content: I think this poll should have more options. For example, an option to drop CR to 1.05, drop the base rate again (raising the base rate seems to have hurt us), with the emergency DC raises
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I voted No. (these poll options are bad) The debt ceilings absolutely need to be raised. We need high stable coin DCs to be available when ETH price is falling in order to prevent negative feedback loops. Ideally during normal market conditions or when ETH price is increasing, these vaults would be near zero since it doesn’t really make sense to pay a fee to mint $1 DAI with $1.1 USDC/T/P. However when market conditions change, we need to have the flexibility to mint 100s of millions of DAI via stable coins. I am against lowering the LRs. Once lowered, they cannot be easily raised and this “stop gap solution” becomes a new normal. If we want overflow emergency vaults with different parameters like this, then I think we should go the USDC-B route and create new vaults. This allows us to handle “temporary emergency liquidity” situations without screwing up the basic risk management of the primary vaults.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Or even several different polls here to reflect the different potential emergency changes

Having several options in an emergency poll is also not ideal. You really want it to be simple to understand and execute. That said, if another community member wanted to create an alternative emergency poll with different parameters, that’s doable. It would need to follow the same rules I laid out above. If it actually follows the practical guide as much as possible, I’ll give it precedence over this one. Which, frankly, doesn’t follow the guidelines, and I probably shouldn’t accept on that basis. Feels kind of shitty to throw the book at someone and block this if it has community support just because someone didn’t put the right tags on a post though.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: So, it’s not okay to have multiple options for an emergency poll, or at least several polls which consider each of the possible independent responses to the emergency?

content.content: I think it’s fine as long as they are really clearly defined and there is no ambiguity over what is being voted for. Having just a single option bypasses that issue of clarity, which is why I’d prefer it.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I am definitely for DC rise in the nearest future, however, against the LR of 101%, maybe 105% is more adequate. As already mentioned in different threads, such low LR will allow very small # of whales to max out the vaults caps (see 201x leverage possibility at just 1.005). Having a low number of whales is adverse due to the big price impact when one of them decides to convert back to USDC whereas having more diverse set of whales will allow for smoother moves.

content.content: New signal request: [Signal Request] Should we take Emergency action to fix the peg?

This topic has been superseded by this emergency signal thread: [Signal Request] Should we take Emergency action to fix the peg? My reasoning for this is that the new signal is better formatted to the signalling process guidelines, offers additional options for the community to express their opinion and also doesn’t include TUSD (which is not currently active as a collateral type anyway.) Thanks to @Replenish2030 for pushing this issue, despite the inflammatory post.
